results.headline: The Setting Is Juvenile, the Problems Are Not
results.summary_short: “Dog Pound” is an update of a 1970s film about teenage inmates adjusting to prison life.

results.headline: His Truck Is Stuck. Really Stuck.
results.summary_short: In “Detour,” Neil Hopkins tries to keep his sanity as he deals with being stuck in his vehicle after a mudslide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Detour

results.headline: A Fighting Mood Over Marijuana in Montana
results.summary_short: The 2010 campaign to repeal Montana’s legalization of medical marijuana is the subject of the documentary “Code of the West.”

results.headline: The Fairest Bullfighter, and Princess, of Them All
results.summary_short: In “Blancanieves,” a Spanish retelling of “Snow White,” the young protagonist is the daughter of a bullfighter and a flamenco dancer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blancanieves

results.headline: Smooth Operators Slink Into the Desolate Night
results.summary_short: In “Welcome to the Punch” a group of thieves is joined in the uninhabited night by a cop, who, from the looks it, is angry, determined and terminally alone.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome to the Punch

results.headline: There’s a Word for a Movie Like This
results.summary_short: “InAPPropriate Comedy,” with Adrien Brody, Rob Schneider and Michelle Rodriguez, tries to be a parody of bigoted offensiveness, but succeeds only in being deeply unfunny.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of InAPPropriate Comedy

results.headline: The Dark and Light of East London
results.summary_short: “My Brother the Devil” is the first feature directed by Sally El Hosaini, a Welsh-Egyptian filmmaker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brother the Devil

results.headline: His Arms Raise Up Him and His Audience
results.summary_short: “You Don’t Need Feet to Dance” is a documentary that looks at Sidiki Conde, a Guinean-born drummer and dancer disabled by polio.
results.display_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Don't Need Feet to Dance

results.headline: Defiant Souls and Hopeful Sounds of the ’60s
results.summary_short: “The Sapphires” chronicles a female quartet of Aboriginal singers on the way to stardom in the 1960s and the obstacles they face.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sapphires

results.headline: There’s Something About That Boy
results.summary_short: “The Croods” is an animated comedy about a Stone Age family, starring the voice of Emma Stone.

results.headline: Cheaper by the Gross
results.summary_short: A sperm donor, played by Patrick Huard, gets in touch with his paternal side years later in “Starbuck,” directed by Ken Scott.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starbuck

results.headline: Apocalypse Fed
results.summary_short: “Silver Circle,” directed by Pasha Roberts, is set in a post-apocalyptic world brought on by the Federal Reserve’s monetary policies.

results.headline: He’s Weary, but Psyched to Save Democracy
results.summary_short: In the “Die Hard” tradition, the lead character in “Olympus Has Fallen” is a world-weary professional battling evil amid pyrotechnics.

results.headline: Posthumous Salute to a SEAL Team Leader
results.summary_short: “Murph: The Protector” is a documentary about Lt. Michael P. Murphy, the SEAL team leader awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously in 2007.

results.headline: Alone in an Island of Creepy Kids
results.summary_short: “Come Out and Play” is the Belarussian director Makinov’s debut feature about feral children on an island.

results.headline: A Free Spirit and the Sculptor She Raised
results.summary_short: “Leonie,” a biopic, stars Emily Mortimer in the story of Isamu Noguchi’s mother.

results.headline: O.K., Class, Let’s Rock to Shakespeare
results.summary_short: In “Hunky Dory,” a drama teacher persuades her pupils to stage a rock opera based on “The Tempest.”

results.headline: Larceny for the Sake of Art
results.summary_short: Two Bronx graffiti artists go on a daylong quest to finance an ambitious project: the tagging of a big plastic apple at Citi Field.

results.headline: The Man Behind the Doctor’s Mask
results.summary_short: Viggo Mortensen plays a pediatrician in Buenos Aires who decides to start a new life by assuming the identity of his twin.

results.headline: She’s Not Impressed? Then You’re Not In
results.summary_short: Tina Fey stars as an admissions officer at Princeton in “Admission,” a comedy directed by Paul Weitz.
